Municipal Building
New York City, New York
Dear Si:
With your full knowledge of ray wholehearted admiration, support, and
loyalty to you and the unbounded respect with which I have always viewed
your operations, you will, I am sure, accept a minor spanking from me.
Very briefly, I am not at all doubtful that Frank’s failure to report
to you and the Board on the financial status of NAEB has been most annoying
and certainly if he has been derelict in his duties he needs to be pulled
up by the boot straps. Y0ur letter of December 28, however, was too strong,
particularly in view of your having forwarded copies to members of the Board.
It could result only in completely antagonizing Frank and should never have
been written. Please consider yourself duly spanked.
May I reaffirm my absolute confidence in what you are doing and my
appreciation for the very excellent way in which you have always conducted
NAEB affairs. I think I have a clearer picture than anyone of the enormous
amount of work and thought and the large portion of your heart that you have
poured into this organization. All of the membership are grateful to you
and all of us are extremely proud of you.
You must realize, however, that few people are as efficient as you are
in handling their own problems, as well as organizational jobs, and be a
bit more tolerant of the weaknesses of others. I have been aware for some
time of the very great pressure that NAEB affairs was placing on you and
of the demands on your time which it is making. You of all the people I
know in the organization are big enough to handle it, however, and I am
completely confident that you will continue to do so.
Loving you like a brother, I suggest that you write Frank Schooley with
carbons to other members of the Board reaffirming the fact that you do need
a statement from him but apologizing for the brushess of the letter you
sent under the date of December 28. I think it will warm up a cold spot
that your other letter created. Furthermore, don’t let me hear any more
baby-talk about quitting an office because it has run into some snags.
If you can’t iron out the rough spots, I know well that I could not and,
what is more, would not tackle the job. I know of absolutely no one in the
